Name: astro-ecommerce-template
Author: Minh Turi
Description:
I was able to fix server issue. Hope the SSR live link works as expected üòÜ
I must say I'm glad that I found out about Astro. It has huge benefit on working with popular component framework as React, Vue which I don't find it with 11ty in the past. So building static site that generates a lot of data is definitely suited for Astro. For some use case that requires complex interactivity on client side I think I have to choose between Astro and NextJS. Still some bugs along development but so far so good.
Thanks Astro project and community! üôÇ

Description:
A project I wanted to built for a long time. Planning meetings through time zones can be really tough. Meetup.day tries to solve this problem, by offering a free lightweight tool to plan your next meetup.
And the best thing: It's built with Astro SSR üòâ

Description: I made this app for YouTubers who are willing to make a website for their YouTube channel. This simple UI will help them to create their own custom website. I had ideas to create a full dashboard. But I didn't had time to add more advanced features so I ended up making this. Hope you guys like it.

Name: ui-gallery
Author: Harsh Singh
Description:
WHEW. This project was a HUGE learning experience for me, speaking in terms of Astro. Not only did I experiment with Astro's experimental server-side rendering and new Vercel integration, but I also built the first application that uses Prisma ORM (https://prisma.io/) and is deployed to Vercel (https://vercel.com/). MAN, I just don't have enough words to thank the people who helped me deploy my application. It was a pretty tedious process which took over 10 hours, and I'm thankful to everyone who helped me helped me it ‚ù§Ô∏è. Now enough of the Sirius (pun intended :p) talk, let's get into what the app is, and how it functions!
Basically, the app is a small gallery of things that I've always kept in Figma (you can find a link on the GitHub repo), but I wanted to make it public so others can learn off of my design work, and my approach around designing components. BUT - any good application needs at least some sprinkle of gamification, which is where Astro's server-side rendering comes in. I have a few fun eyeballing games at the end of this whole library, where you have to try and toggle some inputs to properly estimate certain CSS values in a particular HTML element. I've even built a leaderboard for all of this using Astro's server side rendering feature with Prisma and MongoDB!

Name: astro-snipcart
Author: Lloyd Atkinson
Description:
Create an e-commerce site and start selling products with just a few lines of HTML and Astro components, within a few minutes!
Hi! I'm really proud to present my Astro üöÄ hackathon project - an integration with an e-commerce platform (Snipcart)! This project allows you to build your e-commerce store using Astro components! This project represents a considerable amount of time and effort.
Using this integration you could potentially start selling products using Snipcart within a few minutes of creating your project and creating your Snipcart account.
Snipcart handles payments, taxes, shipping costs, refunds, customer account creation, etc.
The project has two parts. Firstly, astro-snipcart currently contains a set of components that are "renderless" which is to say they don't dictate any styles or content. These are how your site integrates with Snipcart.
Secondly, astro-snipcart-design-system is the optional Tailwind based design system that depends on astro-snipcart. It is an e-commerce orientated design system allowing for rapid implementation of an e-commerce site. In fact, the live demo is built with it!
This is a long-term OSS project! üíØ

Description: This one is an Astro based alternative to Linktree (and all the other ones...). It is based on an S3 Bucket an therefore quite affordable. SSR enables to render all link pages in plain HTML/CSS.

Name: astro-snipcart (design system)
Author: Lloyd Atkinson
Description:
Create an e-commerce site and start selling products with just a few lines of HTML and Astro components, within a few minutes!
Hi! I'm really proud to present my Astro üöÄ hackathon project - an integration with an e-commerce platform (Snipcart)! This project allows you to build your e-commerce store using Astro components! This project represents a considerable amount of time and effort.
Using this integration you could potentially start selling products using Snipcart within a few minutes of creating your project and creating your Snipcart account.
Snipcart handles payments, taxes, shipping costs, refunds, customer account creation, etc.
The project has two parts. Firstly, astro-snipcart currently contains a set of components that are "renderless" which is to say they don't dictate any styles or content. These are how your site integrates with Snipcart.
Secondly, astro-snipcart-design-system is the optional Tailwind based design system that depends on astro-snipcart. It is an e-commerce orientated design system allowing for rapid implementation of an e-commerce site. In fact, the live demo is built with it!
This is a long-term OSS project! üíØ

Name: astro-git-view
Author: Siver K. Volle
Description: 1. The named branches and tags are built with SSG, while the full tree of every other commit - and the downloadable source files for branches/tags/commits - are handled by the SSR. To reach a commit's tree, click on the commit-message in the history, from any point in the tree. To download a particular source file, click the "download"-link on the right side of each file-view. When the site is rebuilding, the old SSG-files are still served until the new ones are built, while the SSR is down. No space for puns, this time.

Name: Astro boilerplate
Author: Remi Weng
Description: A complete dark blog theme built with Astro for personal portfolio styled with Tailwind CSS. Mobile friendly with a fully responsive template. It includes RSS feed, sitemap, robots.txt, etc. with great developer experience: ESLint (also compatible with .astro files), Prettier, TypeScript, commitlint, lint-staged, VSCode...

Name: accessible-astro-dashboard
Author: Mark Teekman
Description: An Accessible Admin Dashboard Theme for Astro with a login page and a dashboard overview. Includes accessibility features such as landmarks, better focus-outline and skip-links navigation. Strap in and log in Astronaut!

Name: astro-collab
Author: Chris
Description:
Buckle up Astronauts üöÄ we're going in together üë©‚ÄçüöÄüë®‚ÄçüöÄ

This starter kit contains a set of Astro elements, mostly built with Lit, that allow for adding quick multiplayer presence. Live avatars, shared forms, a multiplayer drawing panel, and more. These are all the components you need to display everyone's cursors moving about your screen:
```jsx
<LiveblocksRoom room-id="my-room" public-key={key}>
  <LiveCursors />
</LiveblocksRoom>
```

There's some more info about the project on my Twitter:
https://twitter.com/ctnicholasdev/status/1526175957899390977

Name: y3llow
Author: Naomi Hauret
Description:
y3llow is a mix between the yellow pages (look someone up) and buymeacoffee (tip someone).
The profiles are powered by Ceramic, so if you created a profile on another website that relies on Ceramic for identity, you don't need to write your infos again üéâ
What's used under the hood
- authentication: siwe (sign in with ethereum) standard. On every user session and network change, you need to sign a message in your wallet to continue using the app
- UI: SolidJS, ZagJS, Tailwind + cva
- State: zustand & solid-zustand
- Ethereum interactions: wagmi/core
- Identity/profile: Ceramic
- Database + API : Supabase
Upcoming features that didn't make it on time but I'd like to implement :
- More options for tipping. At the moment it's just the native token of the chain used.
- Support more chains (had some issues to add custom chains to wagmi so I dropped it for now)
- Posts (√† la buymeacoffee) (stored on Arweave)
- something with WebRTC
- gated profile (access to certain profiles restrained to people holding certains NFTs)
I'm currently unable to build/deploy due to some issue with the caip package used by a bunch of dependencies (https://github.com/ceramicstudio/self.id/issues/62). I'm quite sad because I really wanted to share it around, but hopefully this issue will be solved in the future üôÇ You should be able to open it on Gitpod though (reach out to me if you're encountering any issue).
Anyway, thank you Astro team and community for the cool tech ‚úåÔ∏è üöÄ ‚ú® I hope to see more web3 stuff built with Astro in the future üòÅ

Name: astro-auth
Author: Osada Vidath
Description:
Astro Auth is a jam packed one stop solution for all your authentication needs in Astro. Highly customizable with a special set of hooks. Topped with a UI library that can be used to whip up a UI real quick.
Oh boy this was huge ! After over 20 sleepless nights and 56 commits, Astro Auth is finally feature completed. Learnt a lot while doing this, it is actually first time that I created a package and contributed to the community. So hope you like it and hope you'll use it in your future projects as well. Let me know if you found any bugs or have any suggestions for improvements üôåüèª. Also don't forget to try the CLI tool üòÅ and read the documentation for more info. :astro:
Extra links:
Docs - https://astro-auth.weoffersolution.com/

Example repo - https://github.com/osadavc/astro-auth-example

Companion npm packages - 
- https://www.npmjs.com/package/@astro-auth/client

- https://www.npmjs.com/package/@astro-auth/providers

- https://www.npmjs.com/package/@astro-auth/ui

- https://www.npmjs.com/package/@astro-auth/cli

Author: Fico
Description:

Name: odyssey-theme
Author: Jaydan Urwin
Description:
Hey everyone, I'm proud to present Odyssey Theme. This is technically the first project from my new brand, Little Sticks. This is the brand name my YouTube channel, courses, themes, etc. will be found under from now on. Stay tuned for more over the next couple months!

I'm still working on docs leading up to the deadline tomorrow but I hope the usage of the components is self-explanatory enough to see how to use them easily.

Also, here is a YouTube video I quickly made today showing off some of its features and announcing the channel rebrand.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7B74jDONNdk

My ultimate goal is to support rendering rich live previews in the CMS preview pane, but didn‚Äôt quite have time to make that work.
